Based on your preferences, I recommend "The Right Stuff" and "Mama". Both movies have been well-received by audiences and critics alike for their engaging plots, talented casts, and overall cinematic excellence.

In the movie "The Right Stuff," it tells the story of seven United States Navy test pilots who were selected to fly supersonic research aircraft (SRAs) as part in a program to develop supersonic air travel capability. The movie is set in 1960's during the Vietnam War, where the seven test pilots are serving aboard the U.S. Navy aircraft carrier USS Enterprise, which is deployed during the war to provide support and protection to American troops stationed overseas.

In the movie "Mama," it tells the story of a young woman named Mama who was raised by her father who was a violent criminal who was constantly on the lookout for ways in which he could get revenge against those who had wronged him. Mama grew up under the constant threat of violence from her father, who she called Papa. Despite the constant threat of violence from her father, Mama learned to be strong and resilient and to never give up even when things seem hopeless.

In the movie "Total Recall," it tells the story of a man named John Converse who has just completed a trip through a virtual reality program called Rekall that allows its users to experience simulated dreams. In the dream that John Converse is experiencing in the virtual reality program called Rekall, he appears as an astronaut who is on board one of the space shuttles which were built by NASA for the purpose of conducting space flight missions. In the dream that John Converse is experiencing in the virtual reality program called Rekall, he appears to be conducting a spacewalk which involves wearing a special suit which was designed specifically for use during spacewalks.

Based on the user's preferences and the given list of movies, I would recommend the following two movies from this list: 

"American Gangster" (1995) 

"Rob Roy" (1995) 

Both movies are directed by Martin Scorsese, who has won multiple Academy Awards for his work. 

"American Gangster" is a biographical crime film based on the book "The Big Knockover" written by Evan Thomas and David Kuhn. 

The movie stars Robert De Niro as Frank Lucas, an American gangster who ran the largest drug trafficking operation in history from 1976 to 1982. 

"The Big Knockout" is told from the perspective of a small-time drug dealer named Tommy Shiloh, played by Joe Pesci. 

In "American Gangster," De Niro delivers a tour de force performance as Lucas, earning him his first Academy Award for Best Actor. 

The movie also stars Jennifer Lawrence as Jackie, an ex-girlfriend of Lucas who becomes involved in the investigation of Lucas's drug operation. 

"American Gangster" was released to positive reviews from critics, and grossed over $278 million worldwide, becoming the highest-grossing film ever made at the time of its release. 

In "Rob Roy," Liam Neeson stars as Rob Roy MacGregor, a wealthy Scottish businessman who becomes an outlaw after being wronged by nobleman Archibald Forbes. 

The movie was released in 1995 to positive reviews from critics, and grossed over $47 million worldwide, becoming the highest-grossing film ever made at the time of its release.

"The English Patient" is a critically acclaimed epic drama film directed by Jean-Pierre Melville. The film stars Ralph Fiennes, Juliette Binoche, and Willem Dafoe. Set during World War II, the film revolves around an injured plane crash victim named Victor (Fiennes) who has past involvement in a fateful love affair with a woman named Roser (Binoche). As Victor recovers at a remote English hospital run by Dr. Edward J. LaVerdiere (Dafoe), he reminisces about his past, the circumstances surrounding his plane crash, and especially the events that transpired between him and Roser.

Therefore, if you're interested in an epic drama film set during World War II revolving around an injured plane crash victim named Victor (Fiennes) who has past involvement in a fateful love affair with a woman named Roser (Binoche)), then I would definitely recommend the movie "The English Patient" (1992) as it aligns with the genre preference of war given in the user's preference cues.
